children.subject: I've heard it's a high workload class, taking it along with 3 techs seems like it'll be a very heavy semester (even if the other techs are easy).

history.content:
<md>I took this class fa19 and really enjoyed it! I would say a lot of it is about the GIS workflow, how to obtain and store data, different processing methods, etc. You do go into the details of projections, datums (conics, cylindricals, etc.), but without any nitty-gritty math. They do introduce graph/network stuff towards the end, for example, we learned Dijkstra's algorithm from the ground up. =

I thought it was a perfect combination of technical stuff on the CS/DS side of things, and the mapmaking/presentational stuff on the geography side. There are tons of topics that the class covers which leaves the student room to dive deeper—my favorite part was network analysis, but others might enjoy the graphic design of mapmaking, or the statistical interpolation methods, or the different internal data structures, or the GPS/Lidar technology, or the details of projections, etc., etc. The semester I took it the main professor (Radke) was on sabbatical but I've heard good things about him too.

The workload can be a bit much, especially if you don't primarily use Windows, then you'll have added frustrations of working with virtual machines and the Windows OS. But overall I enjoyed the class a lot!</md>

I was wondering whether anyone has more information on Geog C188 or whether anyone has taken it prior. The class seems quite interesting to me, but the only information I can find about it is here (and it appears mostly outdated since it's from fa16). I'm curious to know whether this class is more about creating maps, but just digitally, or whether it's involves some more CS topics, like shortest paths and other graph concepts you might find in 61B, or whether you deal with the actual specifics of maps, like projection and distortion. I'm just not quite sure what to expect from the class since I don't know exactly what GIS entails. My main question would be whether the class is tailored as more an application-oriented side of CS / algorithmic / data analysis topics (google maps type of vibes), or whether it's more applicable for the Geog side and the actual creation of maps themselves.

Also, if anyone has any tips on workload / difficulty, that would be helpful too since I was planning on taking it next year as a sophomore alongside 3 other easy-medium workload techs.
history.subject: GEOG C188 - GIS
